Patient has a history of prostate cancer and he is s/p radical prostatectomy/lymph node resection complicated by RLE lymphedema; patient has a history of urinary retention requiring condom catheters at baseline, even before bladder tumor resection on Of note, on he patient underwent bladder tumor resection and was found to have urothelial cancer and prostate cancer 8 on pathology. He presented to with N/V and was found to have Cr 4.6 on from prior Cr 1.3 one week prior. CT A/P and renal US showed right sided hydronephrosis without calculus. Cr improved from 4.6 to 2.7 with IVF. Urologist Dr. performed his resection surgery was consulted who stated that based on operative findings, the cancer is quite extensive and it appears that not all of the cancer was resected. He did not think that urology could access ureterovesical junction via cystoscopy so he recommended percutaneous nephrostomy tube at this time. Plan was to do hormonal therapy for the cancer as an outpatient. A bone scan was done which was negative for mets. On the patient developed a fever of 100.4 and leukocytosis. UA was done and UCx was done which grew GNRs. Blood cultures were drawn which grew GNRs. He was started on IV Zosyn. He also developed sudden onset chest pain with T wave inversions in the inferior lateral leads on . Troponin was 0.52 which increased to 0.55 and 0.59. Cardiology was consulted and he was started on aspirin, Lipitor, metoprolol, and heparin gtt. Repeat EKG was similar to prior with no dynamic changes. Patient was also noted to have delirium, has known baseline dementia. He was noted to sundown daily but confusion had resolved prior to transfer per discharge summary. Per nephrology notes at : Overnight, pt with chest pain and shortness of breath, evaluated by covering physician and found to have EKG changes and more elevated troponin. Pt given aspirin, nitroglycerin, metoprolol, statin, and started on a heparin infusion. Pt seen by cardiology this morning with recommendation for medical management pending clinical course, check echocardiogram and continue medications. Urinalysis yesterday with blood, protein, nitrite, and leukocyte esterase. Urine culture this morning with gram negative rods. Blood cultures from yesterday with gram negative rods this morning. Pt started on Zosyn 2.25g q6h. Pt seen by urology this morning with recommendation for right percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement. Pt is currently scheduled for transfer to for further management. On arrival to the floor, pt reports that he is chest pain free and feels cold. He denies shortness of breath. He denies lower extremity pain. IMPRESSION: Successful placement of 8.5 nephrostomy on the right. CXR : FINDINGS: Calcified pleural plaques bilaterally, correlate with prior asbestos exposure. Are small right pleural effusion. Shallow inspiration accentuates heart size. Normal pulmonary vascularity, no evidence of edema. Bibasilar opacities, likely atelectasis superimposed with pleural calcifications. Aspiration or pneumonia cannot be excluded. No pneumothorax. IMPRESSION: Calcified pleural plaques, correlate with prior asbestos exposure. Small right pleural effusion. No pulmonary edema. Bibasilar opacities, likely atelectasis, consider aspiration or pneumonia if appropriate. TTE : The left atrial volume index is severely increased. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is mmHg. There is moderate symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with near akinesis and small aneurysm of the distal third of the ventricle and hypokinesis of the inferior wall. The remaining segments contract well. Quantitative (biplane) LVEF 31 %. Left ventricular cardiac index is depressed (<2.0 L/min/mw2). No intraventricular thrombus/mass is seen. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size is normal with hypokinesis of the distal free wall. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets are severely thickened/deformed. No masses or vegetations are seen on the aortic valve, but cannot be excluded as the valve is very deformed. There is severe aortic valve stenosis (valve area <1.0 cm2). No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. No mass or vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. No masses or vegetations are seen on the tricuspid valve, but cannot be fully excluded due to suboptimal image quality. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Severe aortic valve stenosis with deformed valve but no discrete vegetation. Moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction with regional wall motion abnormalities consistent with multi-vessel CAD. Moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertention. Moderate left ventricular hypertrophy. Mildly dilated aorta. Increased PCWP. Initially, he was continued on Zosyn, which had been started at for undifferentiated GNR bacteremia. However, on he was switched to meropenem after cultures grew a highly resistant strain of Klebsiella. Blood and urine cultures from and at were also positive for Klebsiella. By he was no longer spiking fevers and WBC was normal. A midline was placed for continued IV abx therapy and he was transitioned to ertapenem at discharge. #R hydrohephrosis s/p nephrostomy placement Patient presented to with and Cr elevation to 4.6, found to have R hydronephrosis on imaging (thought to be most likely due to an obstructing blood clot or edema from recent bladder tumor resection). He also likely had a simultaneous prerenal insult in the setting of sepsis, also contributing to his . Cr improved to 2.7 with IVF at . Upon arrival at , Cr was 2.5. The morning after transfer to a R nephrostomy tube was placed by at the recommendation of his urologist at . The day following drain placement, Cr decreased to 2.3 and then was down to 1.5 on and 1.4 on . He had a small amount of blood in the nephrostomy bag on . Per , intermittent mild hematuria is not uncommon in a nephrostomy. #CAD/NSTEMI #HFrEF (newly diagnosed) #Severe aortic stenosis On at , patient had an acute episode of chest pain with EKG changes (T wave inversions) and elevated troponins c/f NSTEMI. Cardiology at did not feel urgent left heart cath was necessary and started a heparin gtt, metoprolol, ASA, and atorvastatin. Upon admission to , cardiology was consulted and felt demand ischemia (type 2 NSTEMI) was most likely. Given low suspicion for acute plaque rupture, the heparin gtt was discontinued. He had a TTE on which showed severe aortic stenosis, newly reduced EF (31%), and regional wall motion abnormalities including a small LV aneurysm. A left heart catheterizaiton was deferred on this admission due to recovering but will be considered in the future. He will also undergo a work up for possible TAVR as an outpatient. Due to akinetic regions of the LV wall and the presence of a small aneurysm, he was started on apixaban 2.5mg BID in addition to ASA. He did have hypoxia to high on room air on ambulation early on in the admission, received one dose of 40mg furosemide PO, and was euvolemic without hypoxia for the rest of the admission. #Toxic metabolic encephalopathy Per notes, patient has mild dementia at baseline. Has had intermittent confusion and altered mental status in the setting of acute infection and prolonged hospitalization. Mental status improved with treatment of infection. Started sun-downing on and and was started on quetiapine 25mg QPM starting with improvement. #Urothelial carcinoma #Prostate cancer Distant h/o prostate cancer s/p prostatectomy with LN resection c/b LLE lymphedema and recent h/o urothelial carcinoma s/p resection in with pathology specimen positive for urothelial carcinoma and prostate cancer 8). Urology was consulted and did not see a need for further work-up or intervention as an inpatient. A foley was left in place per urology recs, and it is recommended that he follow up with his urologist at for outpatient management. #Chronic LLE lymphedema Stable. Discharge Disposition: Extended Care Facility: Discharge Diagnosis: Primary: Gram negative UTI and bacteremia Secondary: Acute kidney injury, Type 2 NSTEMI, severe aortic stenosis, left ventricular aneurysm, ischemic cardiomyopathy Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Confused sometimes. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. , It was a pleasure taking care of you at . You were admitted because of an infection in your urine that had spread to your blood. You were treated with intravenous antibiotics and this infection improved. You should continue taking the IV antibiotic through . The infection may have developed because of an obstruction of urine outflow from the right kidney. You had a tube placed on your right side to drain the fluid building up in the right kidney. After this drain was placed, your kidney function improved. This drain should stay in place for 6 weeks. You also had an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) because of the heart attack you had when you were at . This test showed that there is severe narrowing of one of the heart valves, which may be causing you to feel short of breath when walking. We would like to you to follow up with cardiology for further evaluation. Please seek immediate medical attention if you have chest pain, shortness of breath, weight gain, increased swelling in your lower extremities, blood in the urine, or fever greater than 101. If you have further questions, please contact your outpatient providers. Sincerely, Your Care Team Followup Instructions:
